Award.AwardTitle: Statics and Dynamics of Spatially and Dimensionally Constrained Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:
The past couple decades have witnessed remarkable advances in nanostructured and multifunctional ceramic oxides to harness their unusual non-linear properties. Ferroelectric (FE) and ferromagnetic (FM) oxides, in particular, have received considerable attention due to their technological prospects for non-volatile memories and storage media, respectively. However, there remain many open questions in term of the detailed understanding of FE and FM phenomena as a function of their dimensional parameters and the nature of the interfaces. This project addresses innovative patterning approaches for creating nanoscale architecture of multifunctional oxides, and the role of spatial and dimensional confinement. The research is expected to provide predictive strategies and design rules for nanopatterned oxides for harnessing their useful properties. The project also involves experiential and immersion opportunity for journalism students to follow the process of creativity in scientific pursuits, and for science and engineering students to learn about the process of reporting and communication.

TECHNICAL DETAILS:
The scientific underpinning of the research revolves around understanding of the decisive role of spatial and dimensional constraints on microstructural evolution, localized characteristics of interfaces, and size/shape-specific properties/phenomena in FE/FM oxides. Embedded in the scientific quest are nanopatterning techniques for complex oxides. Innovative hybrid approaches based on beam-pen lithography (BPL) are coupled to soft chemistry (sol-gel) to generate large area oxide nanopatterns. This approach is necessary to address critical scientific issues associated with phase transformation (crystallization) and phase separation under confinement. Advanced techniques of X-ray scattering and electron microscopy are expected to unravel, down to atomic scale, the nature of interfaces between substrate and nanopattern and the dynamics of ferroelectricity and magnetism as a function of nanopattern parameters and substrate constraints. The research students, including graduate students and undergraduate interns, are trained in advanced microscopy and characterization tools and techniques which are essential for modern materials developments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern science and technology is driven by miniaturization of size and structure and maximization of functionalities, as is evident in smart phones and other "gadgets". The ability to ?pattern? silicon and related materials revolutionized information technology of the past five decades. However, silicon architecture is limited to mere ?charge? and its manipulation, i.e. electron or missing electron (hole). In this context, numerous ceramic materials, especially oxides and chalcogenides (i.e., containing sulfur, selenium and tellurium) can greatly expand the ?functionality? beyond just charge; to optical, magnetic and other diverse properties and phenomena. Thus, expanding this ?palette? of functional materials from silicon to other multifunctional oxides and chalcogenides is akin to providing multiple color options to artists. However, because of complexities of oxide and chalcogenide materials, innovative nanopatterning tools/techniques are required which have been hitherto unavailable.  

   The intellectual merit of this NSF-DMR project, supported by the Ceramics Program, lies in advancing many novel techniques and methods to pattern complex ceramics down to nanoscale. The project team has developed large through-put methodologies and extensive characterization protocols for ensuring the hierarchical organization often necessary for multifunctional behavior of oxides and chalcogenide ceramics. Utilizing advances in scanning probe microscopy (SPM) methods, such as polymer-pen lithography (PPL) and beam-pen lithography (BPL), the project team realized complex architecture of oxide nanopatterns down to nanometer scale.

  Similarly, utilizing innovative vapor-transport approach, the project team further expanded the intellectual merit to chalcogenide ceramics by synthesizing these exotic materials down to single molecular-thick sheets and wrapped around nanoparticles for added multifunctionalities. Embedded in these methods and approaches have been intellectual merit of the influence of dimensional and spatial constraints on materials structure and behavior. The project team helped establish ?form-function? relationships that are essential to understanding of behavior and technological performance of ceramic materials. Several highly cited publications and inventions have resulted from this work. The project team was able to present and disseminate the work in print media, presentations at conferences and through web portals.  

  The broader impact of the project spanned education, outreach, innovation and societal impact in tangible manner. Two PhD students (one URM) graduated during the project period, while over five oither students and resarchers benefited from NSF support of this project, in addition to many collaborators.The PhD graduates are gainfully employed by private sector and contributing to the US economy.

    The project PI incorporated research findings in teaching and curricula development, while the whole project team consistently participated in societal outreach, including ?science journalism, demo?s and show-n-tell to underrepresented minority students and visitors to Northwestern. An offshoot of the concept of complex 3D hierarchical architecture of oxides, resulted in innovations in nanocomposite materials and two inventions are being filed for patent application. The nanocomposite material formulation shows excellent oil recovery properties and energy storage figures of merit. Thus, the broader impact of the project has felt across multiple stakeholders, including potential for entrepreneurship and economic development on top of science, innovation, teaching and outreach.

    The PI is gratified to report that the NSF-DMR support through the Ceramics Program, has been remarkably successful in all categories of intellectiual merit and broader impact; from PI professional recognition, to PhD student achievements to impact on societal and educational outreach to innovation paradigms. The project team, especially the PI, gratefully acknowledges the NSF support and looks forward to continued contributions ahead.
